clusters.title: Connecting cable failed in deadly Lisbon streetcar derailment, investigative report says
clusters.neutral_headline: Cable Failure Caused Deadly Lisbon Funicular Crash

items.title: Connecting cable failed in deadly Lisbon streetcar derailment, investigative report says
items.standfirst: The first investigative report on the deadly derailment of a popular Portugal streetcar said Saturday that a cable connecting the two cabins essentially snapped. Wednesday's crash left 16 dead and injured 21 others.
items.content: The first investigative report on the deadly derailment of a popular Portugal streetcar said Saturday that a cable connecting the two cabins essentially snapped. Wednesday's crash left 16 dead and injured 21 others.

items.title: Lisbon funicular cable snapped before deadly crash, report finds
items.standfirst: Investigators say it had not been possible to visually inspect section of cable that separated before incidentA cable linking two carriages snapped shortly before Wednesday’s funicular crash in Lisbon that killed 16 people, accident inspectors have said in a report.An operator tried to apply emergency brakes but failed to prevent the derailment, investigators added. Continue reading...
items.content: Investigators say it had not been possible to visually inspect section of cable that separated before incidentA cable linking two carriages snapped shortly before Wednesday’s funicular crash in Lisbon that killed 16 people, accident inspectors have said in a report.An operator tried to apply emergency brakes but failed to prevent the derailment, investigators added. Continue reading...

items.title: Lisbon funicular cable disconnected before deadly crash, inspectors say
items.standfirst: A cable linking two cabins disconnected shortly before the funicular crash that killed 16 people in Lisbon this week, inspectors said Saturday. The vehicle passed a visual inspection on the morning of the accident.
items.content: A cable linking two cabins disconnected shortly before the funicular crash that killed 16 people in Lisbon this week, inspectors said Saturday. The vehicle passed a visual inspection on the morning of the accident.

items.title: Cable snapped before Lisbon funicular crash, investigators say
items.standfirst: The rest of the mechanism worked properly, says a preliminary statement into the crash which killed 16 people.
items.content: The rest of the mechanism worked properly, says a preliminary statement into the crash which killed 16 people.

items.title: Cable snapped in deadly Lisbon funicular crash, report finds
items.standfirst: A report into the deadly Lisbon Gloria funicular crash has said the cable linking the two carriages snapped.
items.content: A report into the deadly Lisbon Gloria funicular crash has said the cable linking the two carriages snapped.

ai_summary: A cable connecting two carriages snapped before the Lisbon funicular crash.
The crash resulted in sixteen fatalities and twenty-one injuries.
Investigators reported the operator attempted to use emergency brakes.
The vehicle passed a visual inspection on the morning of the accident.
The rest of the mechanism worked properly, according to preliminary statements.

clusters.title: Ukraine's main government building in Kyiv hit for first time, PM says
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Launches Large Air Attack on Kyiv, Ukraine

items.title: Ukraine's main government building in Kyiv hit for first time, PM says
items.standfirst: At least three people were killed in strikes on Ukraine, including a baby and woman in Kyiv, officials said.
items.content: At least three people were killed in strikes on Ukraine, including a baby and woman in Kyiv, officials said.

items.title: Russia conducts massive air attack on Kyiv, other Ukrainian regions
items.standfirst: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.
items.content: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Russia assaults Ukraine with over 800 drones and decoys, the largest such attack in the war
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.(Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

items.title: Infant among victims of massive Russian strikes on Kyiv, other Ukrainian regions
items.standfirst: An infant was among two people killed in a Russian drone and missile attack on Kyiv that set fire to scores of buildings in the capital, including the main government building, Ukrainian officials said Sunday. At least four people were killed and dozens wounded across Ukraine as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in overnight attacks, Ukraine’s air force said Sunday.
items.content: An infant was among two people killed in a Russian drone and missile attack on Kyiv that set fire to scores of buildings in the capital, including the main government building, Ukrainian officials said Sunday. At least four people were killed and dozens wounded across Ukraine as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in overnight attacks, Ukraine’s air force said Sunday.

items.title: Largest Russian air attack of war sets fire to Ukrainian cabinet building and kills three including child
items.standfirst: Unclear if fire at main Ukrainian government building the result of a direct strike or falling debrisRussia’s largest overnight air attack of the war has set the main building of the Ukrainian government in Kyiv on fire and left three people dead, including an infant, Ukrainian officials said on Sunday.Russia hit Ukraine’s capital with drones and missiles, injuring 18 people and setting scores of buildings on fire, including . Continue reading...
items.content: Unclear if fire at main Ukrainian government building the result of a direct strike or falling debrisRussia’s largest overnight air attack of the war has set the main building of the Ukrainian government in Kyiv on fire and left three people dead, including an infant, Ukrainian officials said on Sunday.Russia hit Ukraine’s capital with drones and missiles, injuring 18 people and setting scores of buildings on fire, including . Continue reading...

ai_summary: Russia conducted a large drone and missile attack on Kyiv Sunday.
The attack was the largest aerial assault since the full-scale invasion.
At least four people were killed in the attacks across Ukraine.
The main Ukrainian government building in Kyiv was set ablaze.
Ukraine's air force reported over 800 drones and 13 missiles launched.

clusters.title: Aryna Sabalenka defeats Amanda Anisimova for her 2nd consecutive US Open title and 4th at a major
clusters.neutral_headline: Aryna Sabalenka Wins US Open Title Again

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka defeats Amanda Anisimova for her 2nd consecutive US Open title and 4th at a major
Sabalenka Wins Second Consecutive US Open, Defeats Anisimova in Final
items.standfirst: The No. 1 seed from Belarus became the first woman to win consecutive U.S. Open titles since Serena Williams' three-year streak from 2012-2014.
items.content: The No. 1 seed from Belarus became the first woman to win consecutive U.S. Open titles since Serena Williams' three-year streak from 2012-2014.

items.title: US Open: Sabalenka wins second straight title, defeats Anisimova
items.standfirst: World number one Aryna Sabalenka defended her US Open title with a straight-sets victory against Amanda Anisimova.
items.content: World number one Aryna Sabalenka defended her US Open title with a straight-sets victory against Amanda Anisimova.

items.title: Why winning US Open means more to Sabalenka
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka had already won three Grand Slam titles but, following adversity this year, her celebration after another US Open triumph was telling.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka had already won three Grand Slam titles but, following adversity this year, her celebration after another US Open triumph was telling.

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka defeats Amanda Anisimova, winning U.S. Open women's final
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka has won her fourth Grand Slam title overall and second straight at the U.S. Open after defeating Amanda Anisimova on Saturday.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka has won her fourth Grand Slam title overall and second straight at the U.S. Open after defeating Amanda Anisimova on Saturday.

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka overtakes American Amanda Anisimova to win U.S. Open women's title
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka has done it again. The world's number one women's tennis player defeated American Amanda Anisimova, 6-3, 7-6, to become the first back-to-back U.S. Open winner since Serena Williams.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka has done it again. The world's number one women's tennis player defeated American Amanda Anisimova, 6-3, 7-6, to become the first back-to-back U.S. Open winner since Serena Williams.

items.title: Sabalenka wins US Open after beating Anisimova
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka won her second US Open title after defeating Amanda Anisimova in a second-set tiebreak.The Belarusian tennis player won the US Open championship with a straight-sets victory and a scor...
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka won her second US Open title after defeating Amanda Anisimova in a second-set tiebreak.The Belarusian tennis player won the US Open championship with a straight-sets victory and a scor...

ai_summary: Aryna Sabalenka won her second consecutive US Open title.
She defeated Amanda Anisimova in the women's final.
Sabalenka is the first woman to win consecutive titles since Serena Williams.
Sabalenka won in straight sets against Anisimova.
This is Sabalenka's fourth Grand Slam title overall.

items.content: Israel has urged the residents of Gaza City to evacuate as it prepares for a full-scale military assault. Leaflets dropped from the sky telling residents of the famine-stricken area to leave. Haley Ott reports.

items.content: The Israeli military has ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to a designated “humanitarian zone” as its forces intensify a major offensive.

items.title: Postal traffic to US sank 80% after Trump administration ended exemption on low-value parcels
Postal traffic into US plunges by more than 80% after Trump ends exemption
items.standfirst: Dozens of operators have suspended service to the US until a solution is implemented on parcels worth $800 or less Postal traffic into the United States plunged by more than 80% after the Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports, the United Nations postal agency said…
items.content: Dozens of operators have suspended service to the US until a solution is implemented on parcels worth $800 or less Postal traffic into the United States plunged by more than 80% after the Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports, the United Nations postal agency said…

items.title: Postal traffic into US plunges by more than 80% after Trump ends exemption
items.standfirst: Dozens of operators have suspended service to the US until a solution is implemented on parcels worth $800 or lessPostal traffic into the United States plunged by more than 80% after the Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports, the United Nations postal agency said Saturday.The Universal Postal Union says it has started rolling out new measures that can help postal operators around the world calculate and collect duties, or taxes, after the US eliminated the so-called “de minimis exemption” for lower-value parcels. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Postal traffic to U.S. fell 80% after exemptions ended on low-value parcels
items.standfirst: The Universal Postal Union says it has started rolling out new measures that can help postal operators around the world after the U.S. eliminated the so-called "de minimis exemption."
items.content: The Universal Postal Union says it has started rolling out new measures that can help postal operators around the world after the U.S. eliminated the so-called "de minimis exemption."

items.title: Eighty-eight postal operators stop sending mail to the US over tariffs
items.standfirst: Some 88 postal operators have either fully or partially stopped sending mail to the US due to President Donald Trump's cancellation of a tax exemption for small packages, the Universal Postal Union said Saturday. In the week since the new rule was introduced, postal traffic to the US fell 81 percent, the group said.
items.content: Some 88 postal operators have either fully or partially stopped sending mail to the US due to President Donald Trump's cancellation of a tax exemption for small packages, the Universal Postal Union said Saturday. In the week since the new rule was introduced, postal traffic to the US fell 81 percent, the group said.

ai_summary: Postal traffic into the US dropped over 80% after the tariff change.
The Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports.
The Universal Postal Union is rolling out new measures.
Dozens of operators suspended service to the US.
The exemption was for parcels worth $800 or less.

clusters.title: South Korea responds to Hyundai immigration raid
clusters.neutral_headline: South Korea Responds to Hyundai Immigration Raid

items.title: South Korea responds to Hyundai immigration raid
items.standfirst: The president of South Korea vows to help hundreds of citizens detained in an immigration operation at a Hyundai plant in Georgia. NBC News’ Yamiche Alcindor has the latest from the White House.
items.content: The president of South Korea vows to help hundreds of citizens detained in an immigration operation at a Hyundai plant in Georgia. NBC News’ Yamiche Alcindor has the latest from the White House.

items.title: Seoul holds emergency meeting after citizens detained in US Hyundai raid
items.standfirst: US immigration officials detained 475 workers on Thursday - most of them South Korean nationals - saying they were working illegally.
items.content: US immigration officials detained 475 workers on Thursday - most of them South Korean nationals - saying they were working illegally.

items.title: South Korea vows 'all-out efforts' to help hundreds detained in Hyundai raid
items.standfirst: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.
items.content: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.

items.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
items.standfirst: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...

ai_summary: South Korea vows to help citizens detained in a Hyundai plant raid.
US immigration officials detained 475 workers in Georgia.
The workers were detained for allegedly working illegally.
South Korea's president ordered "all-out efforts" to help.
A taskforce was set up following the arrest of 300 nationals.

items.content: Dressed in jeans, Nike sneakers and a sweatshirt, with his hands clasped around a rosary, Carlo Acutis has generated near rock star-like fame among young Catholics.

items.content: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.

ai_summary: Carlo Acutis, known as "God's influencer," will be a saint.
He is the first millennial to be canonized as a saint.
Acutis was known for his love of technology and documenting miracles.
He was known for his kindness to less fortunate people.
He will be canonized at a solemn Mass by Pope Leo XIV.

clusters.title: Gaza war film The Voice of Hind Rajab wins 2nd prize at Venice festival
clusters.neutral_headline: Jim Jarmusch's Film Wins Venice Film Festival

items.title: Gaza war film The Voice of Hind Rajab wins 2nd prize at Venice festival
items.standfirst: Director Ben Hania pays tribute to slain five-year old Palestinian girl, calls for accountability for Israeli killings.
items.content: Director Ben Hania pays tribute to slain five-year old Palestinian girl, calls for accountability for Israeli killings.

items.title: Jim Jarmusch’s Father Mother Sister Brother, starring Cate Blanchett, surprise winner of Venice Golden Lion
items.standfirst: The Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing account of a Palestinian child’s death in Gaza, won the runner-up Silver LionUS indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice film festival on Saturday with Father Mother Sister Brother, a three-part meditation on the uneasy tie between parents and their adult children.Although his gentle comedy received largely positive reviews, it had not been a favourite for the top prize, with many critics instead tipping the Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war. In the end, the film directed by Tunisia’s Kaouther Ben Hania took the runner-up Silver Lion. Continue reading...
items.content: The Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing account of a Palestinian child’s death in Gaza, won the runner-up Silver LionUS indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice film festival on Saturday with Father Mother Sister Brother, a three-part meditation on the uneasy tie between parents and their adult children.Although his gentle comedy received largely positive reviews, it had not been a favourite for the top prize, with many critics instead tipping the Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war. In the end, the film directed by Tunisia’s Kaouther Ben Hania took the runner-up Silver Lion. Continue reading...

items.title: Jim Jarmusch’s 'Father Mother Sister Brother' wins Golden Lion at Venice Film Festival
items.standfirst: US indie director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion award for the best film at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday with family saga "Father Mother Sister Brother". Docudrama "The Voice of Hind Rajab", a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war, took the runner-up Silver Lion.
items.content: US indie director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion award for the best film at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday with family saga "Father Mother Sister Brother". Docudrama "The Voice of Hind Rajab", a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war, took the runner-up Silver Lion.

ai_summary: Jim Jarmusch's "Father Mother Sister Brother" won the Golden Lion.
The film is a three-part meditation on family relationships.
"The Voice of Hind Rajab" won the runner-up Silver Lion.
"The Voice of Hind Rajab" is about a Palestinian child's death.
The film was directed by Tunisia’s Kaouther Ben Hania.

clusters.title: British police arrest more than 400 at a London Palestine Action support rally
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Arrest Hundreds at London Palestine Action Rally

items.title: British police arrest more than 400 at a London Palestine Action support rally
items.standfirst: More than 400 people were arrested at a London demonstration outside the UK parliament in support of the proscribed Palestine Action group, the Metropolitan police (Met) said late Saturday. The government banned the group under terror laws in July after activists broke into an air base to protest British policies during the Gaza war.
items.content: More than 400 people were arrested at a London demonstration outside the UK parliament in support of the proscribed Palestine Action group, the Metropolitan police (Met) said late Saturday. The government banned the group under terror laws in July after activists broke into an air base to protest British policies during the Gaza war.

items.title: More than 425 arrested at rally against Palestine Action ban in London
items.standfirst: Hundreds gathered in Parliament Square to oppose the group's ban under anti-terrorism legislation.
items.content: Hundreds gathered in Parliament Square to oppose the group's ban under anti-terrorism legislation.

items.title: Police make mass arrests at Palestine Action rally outside UK Parliament

items.content: Violence breaks out as police move in on 1,500 people protesting against government’s ban on anti-genocide group.

ai_summary: Over 400 people were arrested at a London demonstration.
The demonstration was in support of Palestine Action.
The group was banned under anti-terrorism legislation.
Violence broke out during the protest.
The rally was held outside the UK Parliament.

items.standfirst: Swiss bank account data to be disclosed to island’s chief legal adviser who is looking at source of former Chelsea FC owner’s Sibneft billionsThe former Chelsea football club owner Roman Abramovich is the subject of a criminal investigation by the Jersey authorities over allegations of corruption and money laundering in connection with the original source of his billions, according to court documents.The information has emerged from the federal criminal court in Switzerland, where judges ordered the release of documents, relating to multiple Swiss bank accounts, that had been requested by the Jersey attorney general. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Trump threatens trade actions after EU fines Google over ads

items.title: Trump threatens trade actions after EU fines Google over ads
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump threatened a probe that could prompt fresh tariffs in response to the European Union fining Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company abused its dominance by giving its own ad exchanges a competitive advantage. The president made his warning in a social media post…
items.content: President Donald Trump threatened a probe that could prompt fresh tariffs in response to the European Union fining Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company abused its dominance by giving its own ad exchanges a competitive advantage. items.title: Trump Threatens Trade Actions After EU Fines Google Over Ads
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump threatened a probe on the European Union that could prompt fresh tariffs, in response to the bloc’s fining of Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company exploited its advantage over rivals.
items.content: US President Donald Trump threatened a probe on the European Union that could prompt fresh tariffs, in response to the bloc’s fining of Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company exploited its advantage over rivals.

ai_summary: Donald Trump threatened trade actions after the EU fined Google over ad practices.
The EU found Google abused its dominance, giving its ad exchanges a competitive advantage.
Trump's warning came in a social media post.
The probe could prompt fresh tariffs.

clusters.title: In pictures: Crowds and fashion royalty bid farewell to Giorgio Armani
clusters.neutral_headline: Crowds Mourn Giorgio Armani in Milan

items.title: In pictures: Crowds and fashion royalty bid farewell to Giorgio Armani
items.standfirst: Crowds in Milan on Saturday waited in line to see the coffin of late fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who died this week aged 91 and is now lying in state for two days. Among the mourners were Italian fashion designer Donatella Versace, mayor of Milan Giuseppe Sala and Ferrari chairman John Elkann.
items.content: Crowds in Milan on Saturday waited in line to see the coffin of late fashion designer Giorgio Armani, who died this week aged 91 and is now lying in state for two days. Among the mourners were Italian fashion designer Donatella Versace, mayor of Milan Giuseppe Sala and Ferrari chairman John Elkann.

items.title: Donatella Versace among mourners as Giorgio Armani lies in state
items.standfirst: Donatella Versace has joined scores of mourners in Milan to pay respects to legendary fashion designer Giorgio Armani as his body lies in state.
items.content: Donatella Versace has joined scores of mourners in Milan to pay respects to legendary fashion designer Giorgio Armani as his body lies in state.

ai_summary: Crowds in Milan paid respects to Giorgio Armani, who died at 91.
Armani's body is lying in state for two days.
Donatella Versace was among the mourners.
The mayor of Milan, Giuseppe Sala, was also present.
Ferrari chairman John Elkann also attended.

clusters.title: Judge rules ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants is unlawful
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Rules Against Ending Protections for Migrants

items.title: Judge rules ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants is unlawful
items.standfirst: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).
items.content: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).

items.title: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US
items.standfirst: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...
items.content: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A judge ruled against ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.
The ruling addresses the Trump administration's efforts to end Temporary Protected Status (TPS).
The ruling impacts over 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela.
The judge is US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco.
600,000 Venezuelans whose TPS expired or was about to, can stay and work.

clusters.title: Anthropic Agrees to Pay Authors at Least $1.5 Billion in AI Copyright Settlement
clusters.neutral_headline: Anthropic Reaches $1.5 Billion Author Copyright Settlement

items.title: Anthropic Agrees to Pay Authors at Least $1.5 Billion in AI Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.
items.content: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.

items.title: Anthropic Reaches $1.5 Billion Author Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.
items.content: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.

ai_summary: Anthropic will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve a copyright lawsuit.
The lawsuit concerned the AI company's downloading of millions of pirated books.
Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work it pirated.
The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books for AI training data.
This is one of the largest settlements over AI and intellectual property.
